I honestly believe that this may well be the most overrated game of all time. The only reason that I am writing this review is because other mid 2000/late 90's gems such as Splinter Cell Chaos Theory and Age of Empires 2 are overlooked in favour for this bloated game. Furthermore, people stubbornly insist that this game is one of the GOAT's and yet apprantly still understand the multitude of flaws behind it and how other games easily fix/improve upon them. 

The main argument that people seem to have is that it was revolutionary "for its time". No it wasn't, the puzzles only consist of put x amount of x items here and thats that. It never truly "manipulated and pushed the boundaries" of the engine it was created for. Furthermore, I really disliked how the plot was presented. It never gave any insight to the way things were before the Combine assualt. We can assume it was simialr to the way things are on our Earth before the assualt, but who's to say that it wouldn't be a better life to potentially live under the Combine, similar to how the Empire came and colonized worlds in Star Wars, where they offered the people there to work as Stormtroopers and be respected cicitizens of the Empire? Not once did I ever really feel the need and urge to stop the Combine invasion, as truth be told I honeslty may have preferrred live under their rule. The game never tried to show the complexity of their invasion and how it impacted the citizens. The civil unrest at the start can be written off as a low socio economic region that was drug ridden and had constant riots/protest, potentially even before the invasion.

Gameplay basically boils down to one man army syndrome where you go through area to area running and gunning. Very limited ability to play the game as you would like to i.e incorporating elements of stealth, as enemies will just automatically know you are there, even if you silently creep up behind them. Guns also feel limiting as there have been numerous instances of me blasting a combine straight in the face with a shotgun (which should be a behemoth of a gun, apparantly being one of the most iconic shotguns of all time, only to not kill him (somehow) and yet being deleted to kingdom come when I get bodyshot. Furthermore, the guns themselves are your average pistol, submachine, shotgun and sniper (crossbow in this instance). Despite the fact that the game is set in a distopian future with aleins and high tech shit the only real interesting gun is the gravity gun (which they probably copied anyway from Dom 3, which does it better anyway) and the antlion summoner. No plasma rifles, mini nukes which annihilate small groups of enemies or implants/drugs which beef you up in the short term but have disadvantages in the long term. 

Speaking of the grav gun, I will never understand why the developers waited until the late game to beef up the grav gun. It makes the weapon far more fun to use, yet with no way to upgrade weapons and tools throughout it means that based on fun alone, there isn't any incentive to continue playing. Look at Dishonoured for example. The game has upgrades and runes that allows the player to customize thier own playstyle to how they see fit, thus it rewards them to continue playing as they can overall perform better. No such similar progression exists in this game with the weapons being all samey samey or limited in ammo (crossbow and rocket launcher especially).

There is also a lack of meaning to characters, as Doctor Freeman is supposedly one of the greatest scientific minds of all time, humanity's best hope, and yet in any instances where there is techno babble we are resorted to doing absolutely nothing, but rather watch as Alex does all the button pushing. It honestly baffles me why she exists when everything that she does, Freeman should be able to do. Not only that, but I don't understand his personal vendetta against the combine. Why does he care so much that the Combine should be destroyed? Is there any reason why he wouldn't want to join them in HL2 after all the mindwiping shenanigans from the first game?

Another gripe was the poor level design. Sandtraps was absolute cancer to play, as the "greatest game of all time" would see you use the gravity gun to put one plank of wood in front of another over and over until yu are forced to step on the sand to fight the antlion queen.Really? That's considered fun? I did that solely to get the "keep of the sands" achievement, yet it didn't unlock for whatever reason, further adding frustration to the experience.

A small nitpick, but I didn't like how the game presents itself as a "follow the obstacles" type game. There is no map/compass given to Freeman which can direct him through the environments and which gives a greater sense of purpose/scale of the environment to his quest, it's all about the classic trope of following the obstacles. Granted, in some places there is a map but it's so blurry and unfocused reading it is very difficult.

Finally, the graphics are terrible. Has anoyone actually played through Nova Prospect and not needed reconstrucitve eye surgery becuase the white walls were so monotonously terrible that it resulted in the need  to turn down the brightness several shades brightness. If the game is the greatest of all time it shouldn't look relatively bad compared to today's titles. For example, a recent playthough of Halo combat Evolved and the first Splinter Cell yielded basic but acceptable graphics. The game here was such a mess visually.

Final score: 5/10
